messages:
[{'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-08-04 02:51:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-08-04 09:00:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think we first need to have a discussion on whether to include it in openstack (as part of telemetry team), or just on opendev (under its own namespace).

(I personally think a generic metrics storage DB should be considered distinct from "openstack")

I'd suggest starting a ML thread about it.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2020-08-04 09:27:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

What makes you think GitHub is currently a block for anyone to contribute?'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2020-08-06 01:58:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> What makes you think GitHub is currently a block for anyone to
 > contribute?

I can name some of those:
1. Most of openstack contributors already get used to Gerrit rather than Github for review.
2. Using Gerrit for project maintainer management.
3. Using zuul could help the "new Gnocchi" project involve together with the whole openstack ecosystem, e.g. using zuul template for testing new python version support, new OS distribution support, etc.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2020-08-06 07:16:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks Lingxian.

Can you send me this list of people that wanted to contribute to Gnocchi and were stopped by it being on GitHub for the reason you mentionned?

I really want to work with these people.'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2020-08-06 09:58:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Thanks Lingxian.
 > 
 > Can you send me this list of people that wanted to contribute to
 > Gnocchi and were stopped by it being on GitHub for the reason you
 > mentionned?
 > 
 > I really want to work with these people.

I don't have a list of names but I am one of those. If you ask the question in openstack-discuss mailing list, I believe you will find the answer by yourself."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-08-25 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Julien

Do you see yourself and others who were working on Gnocchi continuing to support it? Because right now we are in a state where OpenStack services rely on it, without any clear visibility on our part that others outside of OpenStack do. Do you have any metrics on non-OpenStack users?

If we bring it back into our fold it makes it easier to maintain and potentially rally people to work on it, because then the OpenStack community collectively holds governance over it and if the project shows a lack of development effort it makes it easier for someone else to take over.

Right now you and the gnocchixyz group essentially hold governance, which means you are who everyone has to go through for the project, and right now at least from our perspective the project isn't all that active. You definitely can add interested people to the project/group on github, but you can see why that isn't exactly the same as OpenStack having governance over the project for when new PTLs or core devs need to be found/added.

There is nothing stopping the project from being used by external parties, and we can continue to ensure that it can be deployed standalone, but it feels like something that ultimately was built for OpenStack, and is still mostly used for OpenStack, which now rather annoyingly is under external governance.

This is of course just my perspective on the situation, and Thierry can possibly add a more official voice to the discussion, but I do think it probably will make more sense to bring the project back to OpenStack unless there is a strong drive to still push it for standalone use (which again, we can still maintain)."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2020-08-25 08:11:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Adrian, you seem to think GitHub or the Gnocchi maintainer group is the problem for Gnocchi inactivity, so you want to get rid of those.

I'm still waiting for data points that prove that this is the problem that needs to be solved to have contributors to Gnocchi.

From where I stand, it's more likely Gnocchi isn't active because nobody has an incentive to contribute to it (i.e. they're not paid to do so, very likely)."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-08-25 09:49:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Like I said above, this change is not discussing "returning gnocchi to openstack", it's just discussing returning Gnocchi to the opendev.org project infrastructure. I agree with Adrian that it would facilitate getting openstack devs to work on it, but I agree with Julien that it's not a magic bullet either.

That said Adrian, if your end goal is to adopt it under the Telemetry team, I think you should open a thread about that on openstack-discuss. I'm not convinced there is consensus over adding maintenance of a generic metrics storage database as part of "openstack".

I personally think openstack should not be in the business of writing a database, so I'm personally against adding such technical debt -- if Gnocchi cannot be relied on (be it maintained on GitHub or opendev.org), I'd rather work on migrating to another DB than make Gnocchi an openstack service and collectively commit to maintaining it forever.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-08-25 23:41:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Julien

The problem isn't that the project is on Github, the problem is that it appears to be a project that doesn't have much usage outside of OpenStack, and therefore few contributors from those sources. In OpenStack it is being used, and it likely would get more contributors if it was clear that this really was an 'OpenStack' project. But people like me are less inclined because essentially it is a requirement now for Ceilometer and OpenStack because Ceilometer no longer has an API, but it's not a service under our infrastructure or goverence. Gnocchi is our API, and it isn't under our goverence. That's just not ok for the long term health of Telemetry.

You didn't answer my question, do you know the metrics on non-OpenStack users of Gnocchi?

@Thierry

The problem is that Ceilometer doesn't have an API anymore. When Gnocchi was built (while part of OpenStack) the Ceilometer API and a bunch of functionality was ripped out because 'Gnocchi covers that now'.

Gnocchi is essentially a core service in OpenStack, but it's not in OpenStack because it was spun off. We are in a tough place in Telemetry because we NEED Gnocchi. Or we need to do a massive rewrite to return the API, or more likely make a new one. All while switching to a different backend that isn't Gnocchi, and hopefully isn't Mongo again...

Gnocchi is essential right now, but it's under external goverence. Which honestly never should have happened considering that it is the API for Telemetry. What should have happened is how Swift works standalone. The project maintains its ability to be run standalone, but remains part of OpenStack.

I don't disagree that we don't particularly want to maintain a time series database, but Gnocchi does solve our issue with Telemetry fairly well in theory, but also happens to be our API right now.

Maybe we can look at using InfluxDB, it looks like people kind of used it before:
https://github.com/mcaimi/openstack-ceilometer-influx-publisher

But that stil means we need to write an API for things like Aodh, Cloudkitty and others to consume, and we'd need to pick InfluxDB as the official backend (while still allowing other publish targets), and maybe massage the data in Ceilometer like Gnocchi does during collection to lower the granularity for older data when going to the 'built-in' backend of InfluxDB. But then we are essentially rebuilding Gnocchi around an external (and maintained) database.

Moving Gnocchi back to OpenStack so we can actually control what is essentially the Telemetry API, and maintain it, is the least amount of effort right now, but yes then we are committing to mainain a time series database.

@Julien

I like your work, but you can see how you've put us in an awkward situation. :("}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2020-08-26 07:04:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> You didn't answer my question, do you know the metrics on non-OpenStack users of Gnocchi?

No, sorry, I don't have such data, unfortunately."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2020-08-26 13:01:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

> Like I said above, this change is not discussing "returning gnocchi
 > to openstack", it's just discussing returning Gnocchi to the
 > opendev.org project infrastructure. I agree with Adrian that it
 > would facilitate getting openstack devs to work on it, but I agree
 > with Julien that it's not a magic bullet either.
 > 
 > That said Adrian, if your end goal is to adopt it under the
 > Telemetry team, I think you should open a thread about that on
 > openstack-discuss. I'm not convinced there is consensus over adding
 > maintenance of a generic metrics storage database as part of
 > "openstack".
 > 
 > I personally think openstack should not be in the business of
 > writing a database, so I'm personally against adding such technical
 > debt -- if Gnocchi cannot be relied on (be it maintained on GitHub
 > or opendev.org), I'd rather work on migrating to another DB than
 > make Gnocchi an openstack service and collectively commit to
 > maintaining it forever.

+1 to everything Thierry said. If we're seeing Gnocchi as a blocker, or if it's becoming one, we should work to break away from it assuming these blocker issues can not be overcome. Otherwise we should treat Gnocchi as an external dependency and work with the project on their chosen development platform, in this case we're talking about github; this is similar to what other projects do with tools such as Ansible, Puppet, Chef, etc.'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2020-08-26 21:21:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

> +1 to everything Thierry said. If we're seeing Gnocchi as a
 > blocker, or if it's becoming one, we should work to break away from
 > it assuming these blocker issues can not be overcome. Otherwise we
 > should treat Gnocchi as an external dependency and work with the
 > project on their chosen development platform, in this case we're
 > talking about github; this is similar to what other projects do
 > with tools such as Ansible, Puppet, Chef, etc.

I totally disagree with things said above.

First, Gnocchi is not a project like Ansible or Puppet nor a simple DB, like Adrian said, Gnocchi is kind of 'Ceilometer API', and it's consumed by other OpenStack projects, it's quite important for features like auto-scaling or auto-healing in OpenStack.

Gnocchi is a blocker right now because of no maintainers, but why not we solve the problem together but re-create another wheel? Why do you assume this blocker can't be overcome given what Adrian is trying to do here is actually moving Gnocchi development back on track? The people who chose the Github development platform have all left, which proves how a bad idea it was to split projects from OpenStack, why we still have to stick with the wrong way?

Moving Gnocchi back into OpenDev makes it easier to integrate with other OpenStack services in CI and easier for OpenStack developers to get involved, and easier for the project governance.

Additionally, I know there are some people already deployed Gnncchi in production, I believe getting Gnocchi back on track is also good news for them. (I will try to find their names and add them for review.)"}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-08-27 03:56:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

As Lingxian has reiterated, Gnocchi is the 'Ceilometer API'. That's the core part of our whole problem right now.

That essentially makes Gnocchi an official part of OpenStack whether we like it or not because it is directly consumed by other services AS IF it is an official API for Telemetry, and it is capable of using Keystone for Auth.

Can we change that? Sure, but that means 'still' maintaining Gnocchi while we write a new API back into Ceilometer, and choose a new backend for that API which can't just be a plugin export target for Ceilometer but has to be fully integrated (or a plugin backend system). All while migrating everything that consumes Gnocchi to the new API.

That's a HUGE amount of work, and still we have to somehow keep Gnocchi alive while we do that. Where will we find the devs for that?

Telemetry is in a terrible situation because of Gnocchi leaving OpenStack, and because of the Ceilometer API being deprecated. It sucks to say, but that's the hard and sad truth of it.

Even if we don't want to maintain a times-eries database (and trust me, I don't), bringing Gnocchi back into the fold is the easiest thing to do, despite the fact that we are then stuck maintaining a time-series DB."}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2020-08-27 06:16:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

A benefit I'd see by moving this back to OpenDev is that we'd catch issues like the breaking changes with pecan 1.4, see https://github.com/gnocchixyz/python-gnocchiclient/pull/110 earlier.

I'm not sure how moving it back to OpenDev would help with issues like CI being broken (https://github.com/gnocchixyz/python-gnocchiclient/pull/110/checks ).

Gnocchi is integrated tightly into heat and aodh and these components provide features like autoscaling for OpenStack. Unlike other projects like libvirt or mysql/mariadb, Gnocchi is rarely(?) used outside of OpenStack scope.

The more user visible change would be: gnocchi is back under the OpenStack roof, and it may imply it is supported by the OpenDev community. The latter would be false, if there are no people stepping up.


Taking a step back, since gnocchi is currently integral part of OpenStack autoscaling, but at the same time, the contributions to that part becoming less and less, we may have to either step up and contribute, find a replacement, or to accept that this feature is gone and users will see a regression."}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2020-08-27 06:34:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Leaving architectural changes aside (re. add API back to ceilometer), personally I do consider gnocchi being a part of OpenStack telemetry. 

Thus I am supporting this step to move gnocchi back to OpenStack. The telemetry team will have to come up with a long-term plan: either get a replacement or to get this all into a more sustainable status.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2020-08-27 07:54:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Let me take a step back because I think some of you do not have a grasp on how some parts of the open-source dynamic works.

None of you ever contributed a single line of code to Gnocchi. So, with all due respect, what you think is completely irrelevant to any of the Gnocchi historical contributors. Understand that we don't know who you are and you are complete strangers talking on the Internet about our project. You have opinions? Fine. Everybody has those. They're cheap.

You can talk all you want in this review about what you think Gnocchi should be or whatever. Be my guest.

If you want leverage over an open-source project, you have to be part of it (= contribute). Until you do that, you can talk all you want, you're going to be mostly ignored.

The current situation is totally fine in the eyes of Gnocchi's current development team and contributors. We're hosted on the largest open-source development platform. We're opened to contributions.

If you spent half the energy you spent writing in this code review contributing to Gnocchi, you'd be way more efficient on the future of the project.

Good luck!"}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2020-08-27 08:09:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'll try to stay neutral, but for the love of *something* please not another API or reinvention of the wheel.

Personally I don't like working on GitHub, but I have atleast tried starting to get CI working tho with extremely little time and very little knowledge into the project.

While it would make all our lives easier moving it to OpenDev (it sure would for me, using OpenDev CI would be much better imo) I dont see why we can't step up and atleast get the upstream project's CI working, check reported bug and pending PR's and atleast start doing releases when bugs are fixed?

We are multiple people that could easily get it into a (atleast more) healthy state."}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2020-08-27 08:10:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Should also mention we run it in production, we know third party software (one of which we use) that support the Gnocchi API.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-08-27 13:26:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

For me, gnocchi is a an external tool, like many other tools or libraries OpenStack consumes. It's fine for me to have it separately. I am not against bringing it in OpenStack, but I want it to be done for the right reasons. I am not sure it's the case here.

Is there any technical issue preventing github contributions? AFAIK, it's accessible worldwide. If it's just about convenience, and multiple contributors don't want to contribute on github on the original project, I find it sad. So far, Julien was not against any contributions. We should build a stronger ecosystem, not fragment it even more.

If people miss Zuul for the project, maybe we can contribute to gnocchi and ask kindly if it's possible to add extra testing with Zuul on github. AFAIK, it's not impossible.

I don't want to prevent people from contributing into the project by -1 this forever. But I don't want to fork (and build future tech debt) out of pure convenience... Let's work together folks :)"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-08-27 14:42:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'd like to stress that if we are not bringing Farfalle (you are welcome to suggest a better name :P) back under the 'openstack' namespace eventually, we should commit to getting rid of it as a whole and moving to a different backend and building a v2 API into Ceilometer.

I know Jean and others are against it, but unless we commit to maintaining our fork under the official namespace, Gnocchi SHOULD NOT be the official telemetry API. But given that it is right now... we very soon need to make that choice. Do we maintain it long term, or commit to replacing it.

We don't need to do that right now, but I will likely end up writing an email to the list about our options once this ends up back on opendev.

I've opted for 'openstack-telemetry' as the namespace so it sounds semi-official and isn't just 'farfallezyx/farfalle'. It's ultimately just a placeholder until we move it officially to openstack, or write a replacement API and move to a different backend."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-08-28 01:51:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Medhi 

Thanks for the comment.

I think we would prefer not to outright fork it, but our issue is that it seems OpenStack are the only users of Gnocchi, and it is pretty much our official API for telemetry. The reason I personally don't want to contribute to Gnocchi as it is on github is that the project is under external governance. I personally dislike gerrit, but as an OpenStack dev who knows that Gnocchi is relied on by us, I feel that we need to be able to drive the direction of the project, and have some governing body that can step in an appoint new maintainers if the project dies again.

I have nothing against you, Julien, or Gordan, but trying to revive a project that only we use while it is not fully under our control from a governance perspective is essentially broken as a concept. A fork in that respect is cleaner, especially since we don't even know if we want to keep Gnocchi around yet.

Ideally we would have worked with you to move the project back to OpenStack and maintain it as a standalone service like Swift.

Based on my understanding for why Gnocchi left OpenStack, it was to try and get support from external contributors outside of just OpenStack who didn't want to use Gerrit. I get that, but it clearly failed, and in the process you lost a lot of OpenStack contributors.

We just want a solution, and given it seems neither yourself, Julien, or Gordan have time for Gnocchi anymore due to other projects and work, someone does need to take over the project, but for us (OpenStack as a whole) it doesn't make sense to do that via github and your project group unless that group and contributors was already active. Either we are contributing to an active project (which it isn't) or it simply makes more sense to move the project back somehow and just deal with it entirely under our own control."}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-08-28 13:57:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

We already had no contributor on OpenStack, haha.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-08-28 14:02:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-08-28 14:15:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

also, to past tests you need a bit more dance, see my etcd3gw move: https://review.opendev.org/747185'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2020-08-28 14:44:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

As one of the people involved in decomposing the Ceilometer monolith into Aodh and the various other parts, before but eventually leading to Gnocchi, there's some history here that may not be obvious.

Those of us who were working on Ceilometer at the time were doing so because we were paid to do so, not because it was reasonable for it to exist as an "OpenStack" project. And the numbers of contributors kept shrinking, despite a fairly constant rate of vendors and using-clouds asking for features without actually making contributions.

Even then it was obvious that telemetry in its various forms (metrics, monitoring, alarms, rating, billing) could be sufficiently generic to be supported by third party software that had active communities. It would have made more sense to improve the existing OpenStack services so that they produced or exposed the necessary metrics but the politics and preferences of the time (2014-15) made that difficult.

Part of the point of doing the decomposition was a) to make it easier to comprehend and contribute to a messy system, b) (more importantly) to make it more obvious that the telemetry projects were inconsequential and should be thought of roles that should be filled with tools, in the same that MySQL or PostgreSQL can fill the RDBMS role.

History bears out the above. The choices for third party open source telemetry are pretty good and if OpenStack can't work with them, that's OpenStack's problem, one that would be much more useful to solve than debating the future of Gnocchi.

As said elsewhere: If people need or want to use Gnocchi, contribute to it. If you refuse to use Github, get over yourself. When I joined the OpenStack community I _really_ did not want to use gerrit but came around because it was more important to make contributions.

I mean no disrespect to Adrian with my response here, because he's done plenty of good things in the community, but I think it is terribly shortsighted to believe that a fork Gnocchi to a different location will do anything to change the contribution profile. It appears moribund because it is moribund and it will remain so wherever it lives.

The only way to change that situation, if Gnocchi really is required, is to treat it and attend to it like it is required. If that hasn't happened in the last four years, why is now any different?

It probably isn't. Try a different strategy, use tools.'}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2020-08-28 14:57:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Let's try to collectively give some love to the upstream Gnocchi project.

To build upon Chris comment I've heard a lot in the past about Ceilometer being built around technical issues (read: polling projects APIs for usage) instead of there having been a discussion (due to said politics back then) on how to collectively solve it in OpenStack and standardize.

Just replacing Gnocchi (not just the API, but storage backend as well) is also a big discussion, seeing as how there were multiple backends for Ceilometer back then but it never really worked properly."}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2020-08-28 15:06:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Even if I'd wanted to contribute to gnocchi to keep it alive, I have no chance in doing that! As PR are just hanging there without having any opportunity to merge.

And I know at least several public cloud providers that rely on openstack's telemetry as it's simple to install, reliable and goes out of the box.

So I'd say that moving gnocchi under opendev is more about giving an opportunity to contribute and having a contact person who can review PR and approve some patch, which does not happen on the Github from what I see."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-08-28 21:15:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Chris

 > History bears out the above. The choices for third party open
 > source telemetry are pretty good and if OpenStack can't work with
 > them, that's OpenStack's problem, one that would be much more
 > useful to solve than debating the future of Gnocchi.

We have no choice but to debate the future of Gnocchi until we have a suitable replacement because people rely on it and its API. It's not just as simple as saying: "Prometheus is the answer!" and calling it a day, because that also doesn't solve all the use cases, and it isn't a simple or quick migration for anyone.

 > As said elsewhere: If people need or want to use Gnocchi,
 > contribute to it. If you refuse to use Github, get over yourself.
 > When I joined the OpenStack community I _really_ did not want to
 > use gerrit but came around because it was more important to make
 > contributions.

No one is refusing to commit to Github, but the group on Github has 3 people, none of which are active on the project anymore. Which means we would be contributing in hopes they review our code and merge it, but for people who have tried, that hasn't happened. Unless Julien and co and confirm their intent to review and lead the project, then it wouldn't make sense at all to continue on Github unless they those interested in maintain Gnocchi control of the Github group. But given that only OpenStack seems to use Gnocchi and most of the devs interested in supporting it are here, moving it back to our infra IF we are the only ones maintaining is is smarter than trying to deal with core devs who aren't responsive.

I doubt the people who control the Gnocchi group actually run Gnocchi in prod (I could be wrong), but a lot of OpenStack people do, and we therefore have a vested interested in keeping it alive, even if just long enough to replace it with a maintained third party TSDB which we wrap with a stable API for internal use cases (because such an abstraction is sadly needed)

If it was active on Github, we wouldn't be trying to fork it, and Julien was sarcastic off the bat when I opened this review to get the discussion started. Which I did because Github was silent, and no one knew what the hell to do anymore about this mess.

 > I mean no disrespect to Adrian with my response here, because he's
 > done plenty of good things in the community, but I think it is
 > terribly shortsighted to believe that a fork Gnocchi to a different
 > location will do anything to change the contribution profile. It
 > appears moribund because it is moribund and it will remain so
 > wherever it lives.
 > 
 > The only way to change that situation, if Gnocchi really is
 > required, is to treat it and attend to it like it is required. If
 > that hasn't happened in the last four years, why is now any
 > different?

I don't believe simply moving it back to OpenStack with a fork will magically solve our problems, and I've already said this a few times.

We are doing this because there are devs willing to contribute who want to actually have their code merged into the project, and that isn't happened on Github. This whole thing is us trying to fix this mess and actually support telemetry so it doesn't fall over. It won't be easy, but it needs to happen because too many people rely on it. We may well end up ripping large chunks of it all out, but right now getting it all back into a working state so we can start planning for the future roadmap is more important.

The first step is ACTUALLY being able to merge fixes and get a stable and running CI.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-08-28 21:29:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Let's try to collectively give some love to the upstream Gnocchi
 > project.
 > 
 > To build upon Chris comment I've heard a lot in the past about
 > Ceilometer being built around technical issues (read: polling
 > projects APIs for usage) instead of there having been a discussion
 > (due to said politics back then) on how to collectively solve it in
 > OpenStack and standardize.
 > 
 > Just replacing Gnocchi (not just the API, but storage backend as
 > well) is also a big discussion, seeing as how there were multiple
 > backends for Ceilometer back then but it never really worked
 > properly.

Again, we've love to, provided the existing github group will continue to support the project and contributors. But given that they have other priorities (which happens and is fair enough) what I think we need is a change of leadership. So either they give us access to the Github group or (considering we already all mostly work here) we move it to opendev if the current devs (and reason it is on github) don't intend to continue with the project.

No one is saying we refuse to work on Github, what we are saying is that there doesn't seem to be a point."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-08-28 21:51:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Yes, and if that doesn't happen, the thing to do then is do an actual fork. Same name, on opendev (but not OpenStack), new CI, that acknowledges that it is a fork and the reasons why. If you succeed you will no longer be the fork.

All this noise about naming, governance and association with OpenStack is secondary to the real needs. Just do open source. Don't do this bureaucratic encumbered thing that OpenStack has normalized."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-08-29 14:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

OK then, a couple of straightforward questions:

Julien, do you have any intention of continuing development with Gnocchi? That includes active contribution, design/feature planning, bug triage, helping review pull requests, and onboarding new devs to the project (both by working with them directly, and eventually adding them to the github group). Also, are you currently running Gnocchi in a production environment, or working with/for a company that does?

Mehdi, same questions. :)


@Chris

No one wants a fork, but I feel like all I've read from Julien is sarcasm and scorn towards anything (and anyone) OpenStack, without any intention of responding reasonably. Mehdi has been reasonable so I have more respect from him in this situation.

I started this review to kick off a discussion based on what information I was given about the state of Gnocchi and from what I could see about the project contribution history on Github (and the dev responses there). It somehow very quickly devolved into whatever the hell this is.

OpenStack needs Gnocchi to continue to function as an application for the foreseeable future, and there are people willing to contribute to it, but doing so on Github is pointless if the people who have the power to merge aren't themselves also active on the project. If not, then we fork it because we have to.

The rename is solely because we don't have control over the pypi targets, and similar, so a renamed fork is a clearer distinction and is common in forks (Icinga vs Nagios being an easy example, but not a good comparison to our situation at all). This review started with the same name because it was meant to be a starting point for: "Julien, are you still maintaining this and doing reviews, or will you let us take over and bring it back to OpenStack?" But it is now this whole bloody mess.

So let's get a definitive answer to the above, and then we can actually figure out what to do. Because given how Julien has responded here, and on Github (and Twitter), it feels like he doesn't care about Gnocchi anymore but also doesn't want to admit it.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2020-08-31 07:21:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

So at the moment we even don't have at least guaranteed docs and CI resources, so really can face up in expired domain or smth as trivial things at least.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2020-09-01 01:49:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Gnocchi is clearly not actively maintain, but for sake of clarity: the pull requests have not been reviewed because the CIs have never passed.

A lot of this seems to be about CI, which isn't working and an understandable blocker to upstream developers wanting to undertake code review.  On the other hand, nobody is actively invested in maintaining the upstream CI (based on reading the grab bag of required changes in https://github.com/gnocchixyz/gnocchi/pull/1065).

Although we do not want OpenDev to be a generic TravisCI replacement, there are areas where it makes a lot of sense to have OpenDev Zuul CI running against external github projects.  Bringing together an inactive upstream CI effort with interested parties wanting to build out OpenDev CI would, to me, clearly be one. 

I have recently had a very productive interaction with pyca project wrt to cryptography where Zuul is providing CI resources for their project (this was not due to issues upstream, but because we have ARM64 resources that are particularly useful, and we get the benefits of having a stable arm64 environment).  Zuul reports in the same way as other CI systems using the checks api, see https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/pull/5428/checks for an example.

Using that as a template, we would have a separate gnocchi tenant for running the CI jobs in.  We can organise things in many different ways; we can create a project-config for pipeline configuration in the gnocchi OpenDev tenant, or upstream could create one and give people developing on Zuul access.  We can keep job config/playbooks/roles in the github gnocchi repository or separate repos.  At a minimum, all Gnocchi needs to do is enable the OpenDev github bot.

This can only work if a) upstream will not insist that the only CI is travisCI and b) that the people proposing the fork are committing to actually building out useful CI in Zuul.

To me, it seems like this might bridge the gap between where the active developers are working (OpenDev) and what upstream needs as a workflow to manage the project (CI showing changes aren't broken).

If people can come to some sort of agreement, which I have to honestly say seems unlikely given the way some of the discussion is going, I can commit helping get this to the point of running and reporting jobs."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2020-09-01 10:57:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I don't run Gnocchi and don't work on it actively anymore since April 2019. I don't plan on actively writing code for it in the future if that answers your question.

I'll be happy to help to the extent I can, reviewing PR for bug fixes for example. That's something we all tried to do for the last year — I know Gordon merged some bug fixes."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2020-09-01 10:58:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Just forgot to reply to a point: I definitely care less about Gnocchi that I did when it was my job. I still feel like it's not a good idea to give the project to anyone randomly showing up on the Internet and asking for the keys. :)"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2020-09-01 11:02:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Dmitriy, I feel like you misunderstood the issue with the domain.

I bought the domain from my pocket a while back and asked my employer to take care of it so I wouldn't be a SPOF. I never managed to do so as nobody cared back then. Whatever.

The domain then expired, and when people asked to buy it back, it was impossible to do so for whatever reason."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-09-03 03:44:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@Julien

Ty! That's what I assumed, but it's good to know. :)

I know asking to be handed the keys when I personally have never contributed to Gnocchi is a bit of a stretch, but I genuinely am trying to keep the project alive (at least for the foreseeable future) and just want to facilitate a solution for those of us using it, or wanting to use it in OpenStack.

OpenStack seem to be the only visible/vocal consumers of Gnocchi, so we (and people running OS, and being paid to maintain OS services upstream) have a collective reason to keep it alive. I'm certain among those people we can find enough interest to help with bugs and new features etc. Once I have some current projects off my plate, I will be dedicating part of my time to helping with Gnocchi, so part of all this was me prepping a place to be able to contribute or potentially drive the project.

My reason for wanting to move it back to OpenStack infra isn't because I think that's the magic bullet solution to save the project, but because I felt that long term if you, Mehdi, and Gordan don't have good reasons to maintain the project, then it makes sense to hand it over to people who might. That way there is no burden on you to care/worry about it unless you want to, but the ultimate responsibility for the project ends up in OpenStack's hands. We have some silly but powerful infra, some complex but useful tooling, and processes to follow that while being a pain sometimes, do help govern the massive ecosystem that is OpenStack.

That's not to say that the TC or the foundation aren't sometimes unbelievably annoying bureaucracies to deal with, but at least if I (or someone else) fails as PTL for Gnocchi, they can step in and hand the project over to other interested parties. Which has happened a few times and sometimes it has allowed projects to be saved.

So while we can definitely work with you, Mehdi, and Gordan to rekindle the project on Github, that doesn't really make sense unless you do want to still take part in its future, or drive it. It doesn't make sense for us to contribute on github if we might never get access to or control of the gnocchixyz group from people who in our perspective don't have strong interest in the project anymore, and less so still if most of us are already all on opendev.org and gnocchi is mostly used by OpenStack. That's why if you don't see yourselves working on the project anymore seriously I think closing it off on github, and moving it back to OpenDev is the best case for its on-going future as a project.

I can't say we will want to keep it around forever given that there is unlikely to be huge interest long term in maintaining a TSDB when we can potentially switch to using InfluxDB (or something else) as a backend. I don't expect that choice to happen soon, and if it does, we'd still end up maintaining Gnocchi for a while to allow a transition. In either case, Gnocchi lives on for another few years, maybe longer. We may even find that the alternatives (Influx, etc) don't handle our cases, or the amount of data we ingest, and end up needing Gnocchi forever.

So please do think about it, because I really just want Gnocchi to live on as a project and I think this (minus the rename) is the best path forward for it.

If we end up deciding that for the future of OS-Telemetry we need something else, we'll be vocal about it early, and allow any interested parties to take over stewardship of Gnocchi outside of OpenStack, but until then we will keep it alive and maintained."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2020-09-03 08:53:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thanks for the reply Adrian. I don't have much to add, I feel I'll keep repeating myself. :)

When you write:
> then it makes sense to hand it over to people who might

This is exactly my point. You _might_ do a better job than us, or you _might not_, and that might just be a lot of fuss for nothing. We have no clue to know for now. And until now it has a lot of fuss for nothing. 

As of today, the only person I'd trust would be Tobias because they're actually trying to fix the CI and make progress while we debate about an hypothetical future. :)

I cannot state that enough: if you want to move a project, come to it, gain the trust of the maintainers, get (a copy of) the keys, and steer it. When old grumpy maintainers get annoyed with young and fresh new maintainers doing much of the work, they just give more and more way. :)

(I don't think you were around when the Ceilometer team started, but you'd be surprised by the diversity and the number of core reviewers we onboarded compared to the size of other OpenStack projects.)

If you don't want to play that game for whatever reason or disagree with the maintainers, as many stated, go ahead and fork the project. I think it'd be hard to justify a fork knowing that you didn't even try to send a single line of code to the project in your case — but it'd not be my problem to justify such a decision.

This is how open-source works — outside of the OpenStack bubble. :)"}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-09-04 03:37:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Workflow-1

> This is exactly my point. You _might_ do a better job than us, or
 > you _might not_, and that might just be a lot of fuss for nothing.
 > We have no clue to know for now. And until now it has a lot of fuss
 > for nothing.
 > 
 > As of today, the only person I'd trust would be Tobias because
 > they're actually trying to fix the CI and make progress while we
 > debate about an hypothetical future. :)

But feels like it has taken a lot of this debate for his patches to get feedback/traction. :(

We can always make him PTL OpenStack side. :P

I nominate Tobias for PTL of Gnocchi. Any objections? ;)

 > I cannot state that enough: if you want to move a project, come to
 > it, gain the trust of the maintainers, get (a copy of) the keys,
 > and steer it. When old grumpy maintainers get annoyed with young
 > and fresh new maintainers doing much of the work, they just give
 > more and more way. :)
 > 
 > (I don't think you were around when the Ceilometer team started,
 > but you'd be surprised by the diversity and the number of core
 > reviewers we onboarded compared to the size of other OpenStack
 > projects.)

I was sort of around Ceilometer during Kilo/Liberty, but my contributions never made it upstream. My background was always writing custom pollsters and writing billing software based on data from Ceilometer. So I know about the project and was watching a lot of the work done on it, but never really got too involved upstream because of other priorities. We probably chatted on IRC at some stage about some pollster work I was doing.

 > If you don't want to play that game for whatever reason or disagree
 > with the maintainers, as many stated, go ahead and fork the
 > project. I think it'd be hard to justify a fork knowing that you
 > didn't even try to send a single line of code to the project in
 > your case — but it'd not be my problem to justify such a decision.
 > 
 > This is how open-source works — outside of the OpenStack bubble. :)

The sole reason we are in this mess is because if felt like patches and issues weren't getting looked at. Now they are, so lets maybe pivot to working on getting his fixes to CI done, and some bug fixes in. Then we can decide what to do.

And forking a project when no existing devs seem to be active is very opensource too! :P


Alright, how about this for a plan for Gnocchi:
1. get CI passing on Github (with myself and Tobias helping)
2. work on fixing some known bugs
3. have a follow up discussion about its future, who its maintainers will be, and where it will live

Telemetry in OS meanwhile needs to decide collectively what we want to do with our time series data (stick with Gnocchi, or move to something else).

If we do decide to move to something else, then I don't know what the future looks like for Gnocchi since OpenStack seems like the only people consuming it. It is probably going to be on life support until we make the switch/migration and fully deprecate the Gnocchi integrations. But again, given we'd be the only people using it, it still does make sense to have OS people maintaining it.

If we do decide to stay with Gnocchi long term, then OpenDev is definitely the place for it given OpenStack is the only consumer, and that it was built to fit within OpenStack originally.

I actually don't know what we'd do. MongoDB is a huge NOPE, because that was a nightmare, but given InfluxDB enterprise is needed for clustering, that kinda looks like a bad option. TimescaleDB maybe works since it's based on PostgreSQL, but tuned for timeseries, although clent support looks like raw PostgreSQL. WhisperDB (graphite) isn't suited for our needs, nor is Prometheus really. We may well find that Gnocchi is actually still the best option for OpenStack despite not wanting to maintain a TSDB.

I'm parking this patch for now with a -1 workflow, but... I think eventually we'll end up redoing it, although hopefully as 'Gnocchi' rather than Farfalle or some other name like Kopytka."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-09-10 11:35:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> > I'm certain that if we step up, get CI working, make sure pending
 > > PR's is fine and can be merged, they will get merged (given they
 > > follow policy). If we get some people working on it more actively
 > > I'm sure those persons will get merge rights.
 > 
 > Yes, and if that doesn't happen, the thing to do then is do an
 > actual fork. Same name, on opendev (but not OpenStack), new CI,
 > that acknowledges that it is a fork and the reasons why. If you
 > succeed you will no longer be the fork.
 > 
 > All this noise about naming, governance and association with
 > OpenStack is secondary to the real needs. Just do open source.
 > Don't do this bureaucratic encumbered thing that OpenStack has
 > normalized.

This was exactly my point. Totally agreed there."}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2021-11-13 19:30:08.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Feel free to restore if this is still needed'}]

'}, {'created': '2020-08-28 00:06:30.000000000', 'message': "Fork Gnocchi back to openstack as Farfalle

Gnocchi is currently unmaintained:
https://github.com/gnocchixyz/gnocchi/issues/1049

Pull requests to the Github repo to fix issues have been
left unreviewed and unmerged and there seems to be a lack
of activity from the current devs behind the project.

An attempt was made to bring the project back over to OpenStack
under the same name where we could control governence for the
project and ideally still include existing contributors, but
despite no real activity from current project maintainers
they appear unwilling to relinquish control.

As such we are now proposing a fork back under a new namespace
'openstack-telemetry' where we can bring the project back to
active maintainence while we decide its future within OpenStack.

Gnocchi currently is the defacto offical Telemetry API as used by
Aodh, Cloudkitty, and relied on by thirdparty application around
OpenStack as well. As such we do need to bring it back somewhat
and maintain it.

Change-Id: Ie1b916725c50c3f06a7d8561886da37839864959

commit_message:
Fork Gnocchi back to openstack as Farfalle

Gnocchi is currently unmaintained:
https://github.com/gnocchixyz/gnocchi/issues/1049

Pull requests to the Github repo to fix issues have been
left unreviewed and unmerged and there seems to be a lack
of activity from the current devs behind the project.

An attempt was made to bring the project back over to OpenStack
under the same name where we could control governence for the
project and ideally still include existing contributors, but
despite no real activity from current project maintainers
they appear unwilling to relinquish control.

As such we are now proposing a fork back under a new namespace
'farfalle' where we can bring the project back to active
maintainence while we decide its future within OpenStack.

Gnocchi currently is the defacto offical Telemetry API as used by
Aodh, Cloudkitty, and relied on by thirdparty applications around
OpenStack as well. As such we do need to bring it back somewhat
and maintain it.

Change-Id: Ie1b916725c50c3f06a7d8561886da37839864959

commit_message:
Increase the timeout for arm64 jobs

The original timeout is 3660 for both openstack-tox-py38-arm64 and
openstack-tox-py39-arm64, change it to 4800.

Related-Bug: #1949476
Related-Bug: #1949704

commit_message:
Add ApacheTraceEnable to set ansible trace_enable

Added ApaccheTraceEnable parameter allowing to enable or disable
apache trace in image serve in order to satisfy security scanners.

Change-Id: Ic3f400ff767354a4792db8106011ae9ba0a6189d

commit_message:
Call driver.rbd.Image from tpool.Proxy

Call driver.rbd.Image from tpool.Proxy instead of assigning
driver.rbd.Image to self.volume and then using tpool.Proxy
on self.volume.

Change-Id: Ic505b5ba0281bc00c5b8e47d6c1d2bcbcf8014da

commit_message:
Add chown_disk regext for /var/lib/cinder/mnt/

When glance_store uses cinder storage backend, chown the cinder path as
this is acutally failing with this error:
2020-05-12 13:11:02.162 33 ERROR glance_store._drivers.cinder Stderr:
'/usr/bin/glance-rootwrap: Unauthorized command: chown 42415 /var/lib/
cinder/mnt/04e1bdb760091e51531be717730c8ab6/
volume-4bb3c895-b5ef-4604-8f47-7663fb8632b1 (no filter matched)\n'

Change-Id: Ic9307f99e16942d641c6c8d2507630f33026b5a1
Closes-bug: #1878403

commit_message:
Implement EnforceScopedTokens to allow usage of scoped tokens

Implement EnforceScopedTokens to allow usage of scoped tokens while
deploying.   At this point in time, we are able to configure the
following:
parameter_defaults:
  ControllerExtraConfig:
    keystone::config::keystone_config:
      oslo_policy/enforce_scope:
        value: true
but deployment fails due to admin credentiens being scoped on a
project instead of system-wide.

Change-Id: I28d04e854e5fb0738a313fdb51e1c6cc40f884fa

[{'created': '2021-10-07 14:12:36.000000000', 'message': 'Append lvm2_allow_list only if it's not empty

Append lvm2_allow_list only if it's not empty as in some case, we
want to simply disable LVM scanning for the host and not add any
values.  If this scenario happens, LVM returns the following error:
"devices/global_filter" invalid. It cannot be set to an empty value
due to this: "devices/global_filter=["","r|.*|"]"] which contains
"".

commit_message:
Append lvm2_allow_list only if it's not empty

Append lvm2_allow_list only if it's not empty as in some case, we
want to simply disable LVM scanning for the host and not add any
values.  If this scenario happens, LVM returns the following error:
"devices/global_filter" invalid. It cannot be set to an empty value
due to this: "devices/global_filter=["","r|.*|"]"] which contains
"".

Change-Id: I19868518bdd70f5b4b261dc5f343e3caa7adb307

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-11-12 09:30:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2021-11-12 20:24:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2021-11-13 09:10:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-11-11 10:48:31.000000000', 'message': 'Add Virtual GPU Config to nova.conf template

Currently, the list of supported vGPUs is populated automatically
within the Nova playbook when the /sys/class/mdev_bus folder is
present. This will populate the `enabled_vgpu_types` variable with
the full list of vGPUs that are supported by default, with only
the first one listed being used.

This change provides the ability to define a new variable
`nova_enabled_vgpu_types` that will populate the enabled_vgpu_types
config option. It also adds the ability to map vgpu types to PCI
addresses in line with Ussuri updates to provide multi-vGPU support.

Change-Id: Icc0c2cd896d4c9a01601d4d733f38443ad8400d4
(cherry picked from commit 3edfbe68963f26a2c11b87094504f8ab37e0abcc)
'}]
commit_message:
Add Virtual GPU Config to nova.conf template

Currently, the list of supported vGPUs is populated automatically
within the Nova playbook when the /sys/class/mdev_bus folder is
present. This will populate the `enabled_vgpu_types` variable with
the full list of vGPUs that are supported by default, with only
the first one listed being used.

This change provides the ability to define a new variable
`nova_enabled_vgpu_types` that will populate the enabled_vgpu_types
config option. It also adds the ability to map vgpu types to PCI
addresses in line with Ussuri updates to provide multi-vGPU support.

Change-Id: Icc0c2cd896d4c9a01601d4d733f38443ad8400d4
(cherry picked from commit 3edfbe68963f26a2c11b87094504f8ab37e0abcc)

commit_message:
Sanitize profile column of ml2_port_bindings table in the DB

With the introduction of port-resource-request-groups extension,
format of binding-profile.allocation has changed. Since the DB,
may contain port bindings that were created before the introduction
of the new format, it's necessary to perform upgrade check and
sanitize those rows that are still using an older format.

Partial-Bug: #1922237
See-Also: https://review.opendev.org/785236
Change-Id: I95e9e1bc553ac499d75c9280e45dfea61d135279

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-11-09 13:00:34.000000000', 'message': "Simplify error messages when running clean/deploy step

The caller knows what step it invokes, there is no point in repeating
it in the error message. There is also no need to wrap the exception
if it's a RESTError or an ironic-lib exception already since they
are normally detailed enough.

Only leave a detailed message when an unexpected exception happens.

Change-Id: I1d8ca1e7ed1462159e4ae5f0bcf58686f6a2681c
"}]
commit_message:
Simplify error messages when running clean/deploy step

The caller knows what step it invokes, there is no point in repeating
it in the error message. There is also no need to wrap the exception
if it's a RESTError or an ironic-lib exception already since they
are normally detailed enough.

Only leave a detailed message when an unexpected exception happens.

Change-Id: I1d8ca1e7ed1462159e4ae5f0bcf58686f6a2681c

subject: Replace deprecated inspect.getargspec
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-15 11:55:49.000000000', 'message': 'Replace deprecated inspect.getargspec

inspect.getargspec was deprecated since Python 3.0 and
inspect.getfullargspec is its replacement with correct handling of
function annotations and keyword-only parameters[1].

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/inspect.html#inspect.getargspec

Change-Id: Id843607e7a416e15f24b820979564193f8e9ab2b
'}]
commit_message:
Replace deprecated inspect.getargspec

inspect.getargspec was deprecated since Python 3.0 and
inspect.getfullargspec is its replacement with correct handling of
function annotations and keyword-only parameters[1].

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/inspect.html#inspect.getargspec

commit_message:
Make cmp_policy_info agree with the API behaviour

When we try to determine the correct state from a set of inconsistent
replicas of the state, the outcome should always be the same as if the
originating requests had all been handled by a single API endpoint.

In the case of storage policy index, the least recently PUT index wins
at the container server API, but previously cmp_policy_info favored
the most recently PUT index if after a DELETE.

This patch modifies cmp_policy_info to be consistent with the API
behavior.

Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ia107c1c8ac051890bea00770f06c53a47eafb9d6

commit_message:
Do not get non-inspur fpga devices when enable inspur_fpga_driver

This patch uses `vendor_id` to filter cause that FPGA devices
from other manufacturers may also display "Processing accelerators".

Closes-Bug: #1949534
Change-Id: I1e59844ac8acbdbe4b4b02b5393bada927a2eb57

I'll approve once I0ebaff67634857216ca8d565311ed7c63f687a16 merges so we make sure this isn't somehow breaking things on Python 2.7."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2021-11-12 21:55:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2021-11-12 23:45:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-11-12 17:19:54.000000000', 'message': "Allow PEP517 without setup_requires

When using PBR PEP517 support without setup_requires were were
infinitely recursing because Distribution.finalize_options calls pbr()
and pbr() calls Distribution.finalize_options. With a setup_requires
this doesn't seem to happen because something is resetting dist.pbr's
value from True (callable) to None (not callable) after the initial
pbr() call and before further recursion can occur.

Explicitly enforce this behavior in pbr() via an explicit update of
dist.pbr to None to avoid calling pbr() more than once resulting in the
unwanted loop.

Change-Id: I1f2b4d34e587389f7e11b99d000e14477cf5091b
"}]
commit_message:
Allow PEP517 without setup_requires

When using PBR PEP517 support without setup_requires were were
infinitely recursing because Distribution.finalize_options calls pbr()
and pbr() calls Distribution.finalize_options. With a setup_requires
this doesn't seem to happen because something is resetting dist.pbr's
value from True (callable) to None (not callable) after the initial
pbr() call and before further recursion can occur.

Explicitly enforce this behavior in pbr() via an explicit update of
dist.pbr to None to avoid calling pbr() more than once resulting in the
unwanted loop.

Change-Id: I1f2b4d34e587389f7e11b99d000e14477cf5091b

commit_message:
Support setting rpc_response_max_timeout per agent

The rpc_response_max_timeout parameter can be set for specific agents.
This change allows configuring the parameter in agent config files so
that different values can be set for different agents.

Change-Id: I6a52a91fe0d18eb0cb4483cb5f5ca3b16fe6afb4

[{'created': '2021-11-12 17:15:51.000000000', 'message': 'Flattening the gateway ip list

In python yaql 2, the expressions are returning a nested list but we
need a list of dictionaries in order to use map_merge.  This change adds
flatten so it returns [] instead of [[]] when nothing is available.

Closes-bug: #1950528
Change-Id: I0638dd35dedc14ecfece3b6b45ae245c41c2b6a8
'}]
commit_message:
Flattening the gateway ip list

In python yaql 2, the expressions are returning a nested list but we
need a list of dictionaries in order to use map_merge.  This change adds
flatten so it returns [] instead of [[]] when nothing is available.

Closes-bug: #1950528
Change-Id: I0638dd35dedc14ecfece3b6b45ae245c41c2b6a8

commit_message:
Add playbook to generate any user defined certificates

If the user defines a list of certificates they require with the
variable prefix user_pki_certificates_, this playbook will create
the required certificates.

The use case for this functionality is to use the openstack
private CA to generate certificates for an API or client that
is not part of OSA, but needs a certificate

Change-Id: If7f57e7eb7335d6bf19a739a25d1e06de3d0cd0d

commit_message:
[ovn] Deleting ovn agents during scale down tasks

When we scale down nodes, we need to make sure that the ovn agents are
deleted otherwise it's going to cause issues.

Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2017827
Closes-Bug: #1949203

Change-Id: I9a253e77178bfe1cdd867a31e8b9adc310238819
(cherry-picked from 1314f345fac2695ce1aef180880d6b1beb630a83)

commit_message:
bnr Configure ReaR to restore with ironic

This playbook configure Rear on the overcloud controllers
to do the restoration with PXE and use the undercloud ironic.

The data will be backed up on the tripleo_backup_and_restore_server

Change-Id: I958439e017efa45f316750a61fd7dfdee5afdc8e

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-10-15 21:00:29.000000000', 'message': "Clarify error message for ERROR_ON_CLONE=True

If ERROR_ON_CLONE is set to True which is case for
all the devstack based job, devstack does not clone the
repo instead raise error. From current error message, it
is difficult to know that ERROR_ON_CLONE is True until we
traceback the code or check devstack-base job set ERROR_ON_CLONE
to True.

Current error message is like:
-------
+ functions-common:git_clone:560           :   echo
'The /opt/stack/oslo.limit project was not found; if this is a gate job, add'
  The /opt/stack/oslo.limit project was not found; if this is a gate job, add
+ functions-common:git_clone:561           :   echo 'the project to the
 $PROJECTS variable in the job definition.'
the project to the $PROJECTS variable in the job definition.
+ functions-common:git_clone:562           :   die 562 'Cloning not
  allowed in this configuration'
--------

Adding ERROR_ON_CLONE info in error message will help to
know the reason of devstack not cloning the repo.

Change-Id: I9e9852f046fefb299b4ef4446323e9c86437212f
"}, {'created': '2021-11-03 19:34:19.000000000', 'message': "Clarify error message for ERROR_ON_CLONE=True

If ERROR_ON_CLONE is set to True which is case for
all the devstack based job, devstack does not clone the
repo instead raise error. From current error message, it
is difficult to know that ERROR_ON_CLONE is True until we
traceback the code or check devstack-base job set ERROR_ON_CLONE
to True.

Current error message is like:
-------
+ functions-common:git_clone:560           :   echo
'The /opt/stack/oslo.limit project was not found; if this is a gate job, add'
  The /opt/stack/oslo.limit project was not found; if this is a gate job, add
+ functions-common:git_clone:561           :   echo 'the project to the
 $PROJECTS variable in the job definition.'
the project to the $PROJECTS variable in the job definition.
+ functions-common:git_clone:562           :   die 562 'Cloning not
  allowed in this configuration'
--------

Adding ERROR_ON_CLONE info in error message will help to
know the reason of devstack not cloning the repo.

Change-Id: I9e9852f046fefb299b4ef4446323e9c86437212f
"}]
commit_message:
Clarify error message for ERROR_ON_CLONE=True

If ERROR_ON_CLONE is set to True which is case for
all the devstack based job, devstack does not clone the
repo instead raise error. From current error message, it
is difficult to know that ERROR_ON_CLONE is True until we
traceback the code or check devstack-base job set ERROR_ON_CLONE
to True.

Current error message is like:
-------
+ functions-common:git_clone:560           :   echo
'The /opt/stack/oslo.limit project was not found; if this is a gate job, add'
  The /opt/stack/oslo.limit project was not found; if this is a gate job, add
+ functions-common:git_clone:561           :   echo 'the project to the
 $PROJECTS variable in the job definition.'
the project to the $PROJECTS variable in the job definition.
+ functions-common:git_clone:562           :   die 562 'Cloning not
  allowed in this configuration'
--------

Adding ERROR_ON_CLONE info in error message will help to
know the reason of devstack not cloning the repo.

Change-Id: I9e9852f046fefb299b4ef4446323e9c86437212f

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-10-13 07:29:23.000000000', 'message': 'Log connection info returned from driver

Currently there is no way to verify the connection info returned
from the driver to cinder is the same as what cinder sends to nova
(or other consumers) to connect to the volume.
This log will help narrow down issues during attachments since there
are many components involved (nova, cinder, os-brick).

Change-Id: I8ed3567f8ae6c6384244cc1d07f1eaafbd7bf58e
(cherry picked from commit 6a0b41a8ffa3b82e4aa646f3d1eaa23b80e57db8)
'}]
commit_message:
Log connection info returned from driver

Currently there is no way to verify the connection info returned
from the driver to cinder is the same as what cinder sends to nova
(or other consumers) to connect to the volume.
This log will help narrow down issues during attachments since there
are many components involved (nova, cinder, os-brick).

Change-Id: I8ed3567f8ae6c6384244cc1d07f1eaafbd7bf58e
(cherry picked from commit 6a0b41a8ffa3b82e4aa646f3d1eaa23b80e57db8)

commit_message:
Add an API config image heat variable

The designate API needs the API container image in order to setup the
httpd configuration.

commit_message:
Add ovn-monitor-all option to ovn-controller

With monitor-all option, all ovn-controllers
do not enable conditional monitoring there
by reducing the load on the Southbound ovsdb-server.

Conflicts:
	manifests/controller.pp

(wallaby -> victoria)
Conflicts:
	manifests/controller.pp

Resolved conflict caused by c60fdb9540bc5dfc60cf05d56ad9d8fe45164343

(victoria -> ususri)
Conflicts:
	spec/classes/ovn_controller_spec.rb

Resolved conflict caused by dba349dad01edafab4a3fda3b9ad813cce814597

Partial-Bug: #1936781
Signed-off-by: Kamil Sambor <ksambor@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ia78c0873e7ac6488b3048ae8475cc87ec40022bb
(cherry picked from commit 7a1bb545198d8c864c619b30f4bc13417d764bbd)
(cherry picked from commit 9879556556e9cb2bc9139799e93da5feb60124b3)

commit_message:
Fix apache ProxyPass arguments

With elimination of CVE-2021-36160 apache stops interpreting trailing
whitespaces in ProxyPass arguments. This is directly not supported based
on the apache documentation [1] and should be fixed

[1] https://httpd.apache.org/docs/trunk/mod/mod_proxy.html#proxypass

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/811742
Change-Id: I9f46466943544168335b07198264adb8be49d261
Related-Bug: #1945274

subject: Fix status_changed_at replication
messages:
[{'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-09-24 14:39:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-09-24 14:44:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

(3 comments)

Still needs some unit test cover to be added.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-09-24 14:44:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2021-09-24 18:42:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2021-09-24 18:43:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2021-09-24 20:50:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think this goes deeper than just containers and shards. I got myself into a situation on master (plus some delta, but not interesting for this discussion) where 2/3 account replicas think they're deleted, but they can't for the life of 'em convince the third one. As a result, I can HEAD or GET the account, but trying to PUT a container will 404. Only, if I list it, it *did* get created! Repro looks like this, all API calls going through the proxy:

* Explicitly PUT an account, to ensure we've got a DB on disk. DELETE it.
* rm one replica -- imagine a disk failure, or rebalancing for an expansion.
* PUT the account again. It'll 403 (good).
* GET or HEAD the account -- it'll succeed! One replica made it!
* PUT a container -- 404? GET the container -- 200!?
* PUT an object -- 201.

Running replicators/updaters at any stage *besides* between the rm and the PUT, it seems to still have the same result.

Even if I run the reaper, nothing really settles -- one replica still thinks it's alive, and the other two keep trying to delete data that's been written since the re-creation :-/

Gets worse if we had two replicas that could respond 201 on the PUT. Suddenly we have a quorum of 201 at step 3... everything from that point on looks like success from the client's perspective -- there's no indication *anywhere* that the account should not be used. Yet the reaper will continually be trying to delete 1/3 of all containers out from under you."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2021-09-24 21:57:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also, https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.28.0/swift/common/db.py#L1148-L1164 surely needs some updating...

Makes me wonder if the status/status_changed_at fields were intended to only ever be a local value 🤔'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2021-09-27 01:02:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-09-27 09:26:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Tim raises a good question i.e. was status_changed_at ever intended to be a globally consistent state or just a local state?

The crux of the 'bug' addressed in this patch is that, on master, replication treats status_changed_at as a local i.e. sets it to "now" whenever delete status or SPI changes, but incorrect_policy_index uses status_changed_at as if it were globally authoritative, and worse, in an oldest-wins sense.

If status_changed_at is not meant to be globally consistent then incorrect_policy_index is flawed: status_changed_at cannot be used to consistently determine the oldest policy index, as demonstrated by the probe test herein. Also, this patch is inappropriate.

If status_changed_at is meant to be globally consistent then replication is flawed, and this patch is heading the right way, but I have now noticed that merge_timestamps also looks very suspect. However, as Matt points out, if status_changed_at is global then should it ever be anything other than the most recent of put_timestamp or delete_timestamp?'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2021-10-18 22:53:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-11-12 18:50:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-09-24 14:39:20.000000000', 'message': "Fix status_changed_at replication

When the container replicator detects that the local DB has the
incorrect storage policy index it currently sets the correct storage
policy index and sets status_changed_at to a new value equal to the
current time. This is wrong on two counts: first, we shouldn't ever
recreate state with a timestamp other than that at which it was
created; second, in the case of storage policy index, a newer
status_changed_at time does not necessarily make the associated state
value authoritative in the system, because unlike most state in Swift,
an *older* storage policy index may be considered authoritative.

When the local storage policy index is deemed incorrect, the
replicator should change the storage policy index *and* the
status_changed_at values to match the remote info. However, the
set_storage_policy_index() method would previously disallow
status_changed_at being set to a value older than its current value,
preventing the replicator from doing the right thing.

This patch changes set_storage_policy_index() to allow the
status_changed_at to go backwards, and changes the container
replicator to set the status_changed_at to match the remote info.

Change-Id: I04686788f01ced6992848caec4a42f5d1461b296
"}]
commit_message:
Fix status_changed_at replication

When the container replicator detects that the local DB has the
incorrect storage policy index it currently sets the correct storage
policy index and sets status_changed_at to a new value equal to the
current time. This is wrong on two counts: first, we shouldn't ever
recreate state with a timestamp other than that at which it was
created; second, in the case of storage policy index, a newer
status_changed_at time does not necessarily make the associated state
value authoritative in the system, because unlike most state in Swift,
an *older* storage policy index may be considered authoritative.

When the local storage policy index is deemed incorrect, the
replicator should change the storage policy index *and* the
status_changed_at values to match the remote info. However, the
set_storage_policy_index() method would previously disallow
status_changed_at being set to a value older than its current value,
preventing the replicator from doing the right thing.

This patch changes set_storage_policy_index() to allow the
status_changed_at to go backwards, and changes the container
replicator to set the status_changed_at to match the remote info.

Change-Id: I04686788f01ced6992848caec4a42f5d1461b296

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-11-11 23:16:54.000000000', 'message': "Drop non-ASCII character from manila config

Noticed the issue with packstack deployment
on CentOS 9-Stream[1]. The issue is raised
by puppet when non-utf8 encoding is used like
LANG=en_US or LANG=C.

Other option is to force LANG=en_US.UTF-8
with the deployment but just for this
description help(all other services working fine),
doesn't look good so proposing to drop that non-ASCII
character.

Issue got caught in CentOS 9-Stream only as it
disabled locale forwarding in OpenSSH by default[2].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/x/packstack/+/816796
[2] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2002734

Change-Id: Ia99cc5313bed950e3363ae311b741395d60eb57b
(cherry picked from commit 5bf206285de3aa61b56ee6c83ffd36e9c1617860)
"}]
commit_message:
Drop non-ASCII character from manila config

Noticed the issue with packstack deployment
on CentOS 9-Stream[1]. The issue is raised
by puppet when non-utf8 encoding is used like
LANG=en_US or LANG=C.

Other option is to force LANG=en_US.UTF-8
with the deployment but just for this
description help(all other services working fine),
doesn't look good so proposing to drop that non-ASCII
character.

Issue got caught in CentOS 9-Stream only as it
disabled locale forwarding in OpenSSH by default[2].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/x/packstack/+/816796
[2] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2002734

Change-Id: Ia99cc5313bed950e3363ae311b741395d60eb57b
(cherry picked from commit 5bf206285de3aa61b56ee6c83ffd36e9c1617860)

commit_message:
Improve storage policy index reconciliation unit tests

Change reconciler unit tests to use headers returned from real
container server instances when testing the policy index
reconciliation code. In doing so, verify that the reconciler code
reaches same outcomes as the container server API.

Related-Change: Ia107c1c8ac051890bea00770f06c53a47eafb9d6
Change-Id: I37a18dfbe3a6ea5ee01600fd4941943baa4b17d6

commit_message:
Add support of keystone unified limits from glance to use quotas

Adding 'use_keystone_limits' parameter, which will allow Glance to
retrieve limits set in keystone for resource consumption and enforce
them against API users.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/812766
Change-Id: I5977d0cd62454d70028a25aaa6206b490884f325

commit_message:
Add microversion schemas for os-instance-actions

I need to use os-instance-actions API in a waiter that is called from
multiple microversion tests in a later patch. So this patch adds the
microversion schemas for this API.

blueprint: qos-minimum-guaranteed-packet-rate
Change-Id: I010fbb4236ccaedb3de663e32eb22f89931d53c7

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-11-12 08:12:14.000000000', 'message': "Use file locks in connectors

Currently os-brick is using in-process locks that will only prevent concurrent
access to critical sections to threads within a single process.

But based on the comment from iSCSI it seems like the code assumed that
these were file based locks that prevented concurrent access from
multiple processes.

Mentioned iSCSI comment is being removed because it's not correct that
our current retry mechanism will work with connect and disconnect
concurrency issues.

The reason why we haven't seen errors in Nova is because it runs a
single process and locks will be effective.

This is probably also not an issue in some transport protocols, such as
FC and RBD, and it wouldn't be an issue in iSCSI connections that don't
share targets.

But for others, such as  iSCSI with shared targets and NVMe-OF, not
using file locks will create race conditions in the following cases:

- More than 1 cinder backend: Because we can have one backend doing a
  detach in a create volume from image and the other an attach for an
  offline migration.

- Backup/Restore if backup and volume services are running on the same
  host.

- HCI scenarios where cinder volume and nova compute are running on the
  same host, even if the same lock path if configured.

- Glance using Cinder as backend and is running on the same node as
  cinder-volume or cinder-backup.

The problematic race conditions happen because the disconnect will do a
logout of the iSCSI target once the connect call has already confirmed
that the session to the target exists.

We could just add the file locks to iSCSI and NVMe, but I think it's
safer to add it to all the connectors and then, after proper testing, we
can can change back the locks that can be changed, and remove or reduce
the critical section in others.

Closes-Bug: #1947370
Change-Id: I6f7f7d19540361204d4ae3ead2bd6dcddb8fcd68

commit_message:
Use file locks in connectors

Currently os-brick is using in-process locks that will only prevent concurrent
access to critical sections to threads within a single process.

But based on the comment from iSCSI it seems like the code assumed that
these were file based locks that prevented concurrent access from
multiple processes.

Mentioned iSCSI comment is being removed because it's not correct that
our current retry mechanism will work with connect and disconnect
concurrency issues.

The reason why we haven't seen errors in Nova is because it runs a
single process and locks will be effective.

This is probably also not an issue in some transport protocols, such as
FC and RBD, and it wouldn't be an issue in iSCSI connections that don't
share targets.

But for others, such as  iSCSI with shared targets and NVMe-OF, not
using file locks will create race conditions in the following cases:

- More than 1 cinder backend: Because we can have one backend doing a
  detach in a create volume from image and the other an attach for an
  offline migration.

- Backup/Restore if backup and volume services are running on the same
  host.

- HCI scenarios where cinder volume and nova compute are running on the
  same host, even if the same lock path if configured.

- Glance using Cinder as backend and is running on the same node as
  cinder-volume or cinder-backup.

The problematic race conditions happen because the disconnect will do a
logout of the iSCSI target once the connect call has already confirmed
that the session to the target exists.

We could just add the file locks to iSCSI and NVMe, but I think it's
safer to add it to all the connectors and then, after proper testing, we
can can change back the locks that can be changed, and remove or reduce
the critical section in others.

Closes-Bug: #1947370
Change-Id: I6f7f7d19540361204d4ae3ead2bd6dcddb8fcd68
(cherry picked from commit 6a43669edc583f8fbcfb4c0f1c7bf6cebad9abd7)
(cherry picked from commit 19a4820f5c4ccca10d50d08198873b1515ee257b)
Conflicts: os_brick/initiator/connectors/iscsi.py
(cherry picked from commit 08ddf69d648c5622a5a300a8636bda727b5b2722)
Conflicts: os_brick/initiator/connectors/nvmeof.py
(cherry picked from commit b03eca8353f1db7fed5dc630d225126b1edb1055)
Conflicts: os_brick/tests/base.py

commit_message:
Don't pass kwargs to connection.execute()

Resolve the following RemovedIn20Warning warning:

  The connection.execute() method in SQLAlchemy 2.0 will accept
  parameters as a single dictionary or a single sequence of dictionaries
  only. Parameters passed as keyword arguments, tuples or positionally
  oriented dictionaries and/or tuples will no longer be accepted.

Change-Id: I44675fce86337696b6494abc03e8058af32686c6
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
